# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 347, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 150, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 855, 603]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- For \(\pi\) , use either your calculator value or 3.142.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 75, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 106, 782, 125]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 155, 675, 174]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 203, 683, 222]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 247, 680, 275]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 295, 683, 323]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 348, 656, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 367, 560, 402]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 446, 225, 463]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 437, 905, 477]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 523]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 217, 571]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 555, 667, 595]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 631, 217, 647]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 630, 570, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 740, 158, 756]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 738, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 240, 845]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 823, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 421, 95]]<|/det|>
1 A curve has equation \(y=x^{2}+2 x-3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 109, 918, 141]]<|/det|>
(a) Use the method of completing the square to find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 327, 144, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 325, 754, 343]]<|/det|>
(b) On the axes, sketch the curve, stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 368, 694, 650]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 366, 91]]<|/det|>
2 In this question, \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 88, 702, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(2 x^{2}+(3 k-2) x+k=0\) has roots that are real and distinct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 395, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 415, 97, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 415, 444, 433]]<|/det|>
3 A sports club has the following members.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 438, 638, 456]]<|/det|>
5 runners, 4 swimmers, 3 gymnasts

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 470, 144, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 469, 463, 486]]<|/det|>
(a) These members stand in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 498, 918, 532]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when all the runners stand together, all the swimmers stand together and all the gymnasts stand together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 670, 144, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 669, 539, 687]]<|/det|>
(b) Four of these members are selected for an event.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 700, 918, 733]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when at least one runner, at least one swimmer and at least one gymnast must be selected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 549, 91]]<|/det|>
4 The coordinates of points \(A, B, C\) and \(D\) are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 96, 672, 115]]<|/det|>
\[
A(-4,3) \quad B(6,-9) \quad C(15,10) \quad D(14,-1)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 425, 145]]<|/det|>
The line \(L\) has equation \(y=11 x-75\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 620, 163]]<|/det|>
The perpendicular bisector of the line \(A B\) meets \(L\) at the point \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 177, 356, 193]]<|/det|>
Find the area of triangle \(C D E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 78, 99, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
5 Given that \(y=x^{2} \tan \frac{x}{2}\), use calculus to find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) to \(\frac{\pi}{3}+h\), where \(h\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 76, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
6 (a) Using an appropriate quadratic factorisation, find the first three terms in the binomial expansion of \((9 x^{2}+12 x+4)^{5}\), in ascending powers of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 111, 444, 127]]<|/det|>
You must simplify your coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 483, 144, 499]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 472, 665, 505]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{6}{x^{2}}+\frac{x^{4}}{2}\right)^{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 78, 144, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 606, 95]]<|/det|>
7 (a) The function \(f\) is defined by \(f(x)=2 \mathrm{e}^{-x}+3\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 108, 918, 144]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y=f(x)\) and hence, on the same axes, sketch the graph of \(y=f^{-1}(x)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 144, 264, 160]]<|/det|>
Show clearly

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 160, 787, 177]]<|/det|>
· the positions of any points where your graphs meet the coordinate axes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 175, 485, 191]]<|/det|>
· the positions of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 217, 695, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 84, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 623, 106]]<|/det|>
(b) The function \(g\) is defined by \(g(x)=2-\frac{3}{\mathrm{e}^{x}+2}\) for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 112, 725, 133]]<|/det|>
Given that \(g^{-1}\) exists, find an expression for \(g^{-1}(x)\) and state its domain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 79, 99, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 81, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 625, 97]]<|/det|>
8 (a) Solve the equation \((2-3 \cot x) \cos x=0\) for \(0<x \leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 918, 95]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the equation \(2 \operatorname{cosec}(2 \theta+1)-12 \sin (2 \theta+1)=5\), where \(\theta\) is in radians and \(-1 \leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 700, 91]]<|/det|>
9 In this question, all lengths are in centimetres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 102, 833, 268]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 301, 625, 318]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(A O B\) of a circle, centre \(O\), radius 15 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 322, 262, 345]]<|/det|>
Angle \(A O B=\frac{6 \pi}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 346, 675, 364]]<|/det|>
The sector is made into a cone with points \(A\) and \(B\) touching, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 377, 144, 394]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 377, 477, 394]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the curved surface area of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 441, 517]]<|/det|>
<pre>The top of the cone is a horizontal circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 533, 144, 550]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 533, 489, 550]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the circumference of the circular top.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 672, 144, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 670, 791, 688]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence find the radius of the circular top and the perpendicular height of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 393, 91]]<|/det|>
(d) Water is poured into the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 88, 863, 107]]<|/det|>
When the depth of the water in the cone is \(h\), the radius of the circular top of the water is \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 122, 185, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 121, 494, 138]]<|/det|>
(i) Find an expression for \(r\) in terms of \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 306, 188, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 768, 323]]<|/det|>
(ii) The water is poured into the cone at a constant rate of \(27 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 336, 866, 355]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the depth of the water is rising when the depth of the water is 4 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 406, 91]]<|/det|>
10 A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 87, 752, 107]]<|/det|>
\(t\) seconds after passing a fixed point, \(O\), the acceleration of \(P\), \(a \mathrm{ms}^{-2}\), is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 121, 626, 164]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
a=t^{2}-2 & \text { for } 0 \leqslant t \leqslant 4 \\
a=19-5 \mathrm{e}^{8-2 t} & \text { for } 4 \leqslant t \leqslant 10 .
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 186, 744, 215]]<|/det|>
When \(t=3\), the velocity of \(P\) is \(- \frac{1}{3} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and its displacement from \(O\) is \(- \frac{1}{4} \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 231, 144, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 231, 185, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 230, 465, 247]]<|/det|>
(a) (i) Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(t=4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 188, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 492, 567, 511]]<|/det|>
(ii) Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t=4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 537, 94]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t=10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 861, 664, 878]]<|/det|>
Question 11 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 107, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 705, 91]]<|/det|>
11 A geometric progression has first term \(a\) and common ratio \(r\), where \(r>0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 89, 583, 106]]<|/det|>
The sum of the 2nd and 3rd terms of the progression is 168.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 584, 121]]<|/det|>
The sum of the 4th and 5th terms of the progression is 94.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 138, 144, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 138, 443, 154]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the 6th term of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 585, 144, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 585, 492, 602]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the sum to infinity of the progression.
